_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Executive Summary contains the facility's administrative and operational programs to prevent ammonia and sulfur dioxide-related accidents and reduce potential risks.  The regulated substances of concern and focus of this document are ammonia and sulfur dioxide.  The following topics are addressed in this Executive Summary:

* Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

* Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

* Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

* Five Year Accident History

* Emergency Response Program

* Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Note: Although the facility has only 4,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide on site, less than the RMP threshold quantity of 5,000 pounds, the sulfur dioxide is regulated under the California Accidental Release Prevention Program, and thus was included in RMP submittal documentation.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Wine Group - McFarland, California facility, located in McFarland, California, utilizes anhydrous ammonia and sulfur dioxide in wine making and storage processes.  

Anhydrous ammonia is utilized as a refrigerant in a closed system that cycles the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again.  The system, consisting of vessels, piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration to accommodate the storage and production of wine products.  

Sulfur dioxide, also in a closed system, is used at The Wine GroupÂ¿s facility to sparge the headspace of the wine tanks, which displaces air from the surface of the wine, preventing unwanted organism growth on the surface of the wine.  Sulfur Dioxide is also injected directly into the wine products to meet sulfur compound level specifications. 

Senior management at the facili

ty is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all employees and the surrounding communities.  Senior management administers the safety and environmental policies and programs.  These programs include but are not limited to forklift safety, hazard communications, lockout/tagout, Hazardous Materials Emergency Business Plan, employee safety manuals, manufacturersÂ¿ documentation, Emergency Response, as well as the Risk Management Plan.

The Wine Group - McFarland, California facility has independently coordinated emergency response efforts with the local Fire Department.  In the case of an ammonia or sulfur dioxide related emergency, it is the policy of The Wine Group - McFarland, California to evacuate the employees and to allow the fire department/HazMat team to respond to the emergency.  In the specific case of a sulfur dioxide emergency, the facilityÂ¿s supplier of sulfur dioxide, Snowden Enterprises, is also available, and qualified, to assist in the response effort.  If an ammonia or sulfur dioxide release could potentially impact the local community, a Community Notification Plan would be activated. If an ammonia or a sulfur dioxide release were to extend into the neighboring community, a Shelter In Place plan would go into effect.  

The ammonia systems and the sulfur dioxide system are closed loop, and there are no emissions or planned releases of ammonia or sulfur dioxide.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Wine Group - McFarland, California facility is located at 31795 Whisler Road in McFarland, California. The facility is on Highway 99 at Whisler Road.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with a mixture of agricultural and sparse residential areas.     

Ammonia Systems

In order to conduct operations, The Wine Group - McFarland, California maintains a refrigeration system that contains a total of approximately 14,000 pounds

of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance.  The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration to accommodate the storage and production of wine products.

Sulfur Dioxide System

The Wine Group, Inc. stores sulfur dioxide in two one-ton containers at one filling station at the winery.  The one-ton containers serve as the supply to fill smaller hand-held sulfur dioxide cylinders Â¿gunsÂ¿ (6 pound and 100 pound portable gun cylinders).  The portable dispensing Â¿gunsÂ¿ are filled at the one ton container and transported throughout the facility as needed for the wine making process. The sulfur dioxide containers and guns are always outdoors.  Sulfur dioxide is used at The Wine GroupÂ¿s facility to sparge the headspace of the wine tanks, which displaces air from the surface of the wine, preventing unwanted organism growth on the surface of the wine.  Sulfur Dioxide is also injected directly into the wine products to meet sulfur compound level specifications.    


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Wine Group - McFarland, California ammonia and sulfur dioxide systems have many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. 

The Process Safety Management program ensures that all security and safety procedures are addressed.  The staff at the facility is trained in operation, maintenance and emergency procedures related to the operation of the ammonia and sulfur dioxide systems.  All pressure vessels in the ammonia system are equipped with relief valves that vent to the atmosphere at a certain pressure set point. Also, all sulfur dioxide one-ton containers are equipped with fusible relief plugs to prevent pressure

build up beyond safe equipment operation levels.  A preventative maintenance program assures that equipment is maintained and serviced on a regular schedule and that worn, aging, or defective components are replaced as required to maintain equipment in good operating condition.  Controls and safety devices are inspected regularly to ensure proper operation.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no significant releases of ammonia or sulfur dioxide that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity (100 pounds for ammonia, 500 pounds for sulfur dioxide) or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years (May 2004 through May 2009).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release, nor any releases or Â¿near missesÂ¿ that warranted an internal incident investigation.  


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Wine Group - McFarland, California facility has an emergency response plan in effect.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of the PSM/RMP/CalARP document, which is maintained at the facility:

  1.) To save lives.
  2.) To minimize and avoid injuries.
  3.) To protect the environment.
  4.) To minimize property damage.

The Wine Group - McFarland, California facility maintains a safety committee whose members include the designated Emergency Coordinator for the facility.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations, as well as to incorporate facility changes.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analyses (performed separate

ly for each system), including a Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) study and a Facility Inspection, provided mitigation measures to improve safety at The Wine Group - McFarland, California facility located at 31795 Whisler Road in McFarland, California. The Wine Group - McFarland, California safety committee is planning to complete several items over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility safety plan/programs.
2. Continue to have employee involvement in safety plan development.
3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.
4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
